title: 114_s1165
content: The Act may be cited as the "Protecting Students from Worthless Degrees Act" and includes consumer protections for students. The "Federal financial assistance program" refers to programs authorized and funded by the Federal Government under various provisions of law, including the Higher Education Act of 1965, the Workforce Innovation and Opportunity Act, the Workforce Investment Act of 1998, the Adult Education and Family Literacy Act, and specific chapters of title 10 and title 38 of the United States Code. The term "institution of higher education" is defined in various federal laws, including the Higher Education Act of 1965 and the Workforce Investment Act of 1998. The term "postsecondary educational institution" is defined in the Adult Education and Family Literacy Act. The term "postsecondary educational institution" is defined in the Adult Education and Family Literacy Act. In relation to specific programs authorized under different paragraphs, the term "educational institution" is further defined as an institution that awards a degree or certificate and is located in any State. The term "State" includes the several States of the United States, the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico, and the District of Columbia. The text discusses the eligibility of institutions of higher education to participate in Federal financial assistance programs for postsecondary education or training. It includes a list of territories and freely associated states that are covered by the regulations. The text discusses the eligibility of institutions of higher education for Federal financial assistance programs, including requirements for entry into recognized occupations or professions. Students must be fully qualified within 1 year of the Act's enactment to take exams for their profession in their area. The Secretary of Education will establish regulations for higher education institutions regarding pre-accredited programs, ensuring compliance with accreditation requirements and timely placement for pre-licensure requirements. The Secretary of Education will establish regulations for institutions of higher education in pre-accredited status, including limitations on program advertisement. Eligibility for federal financial assistance programs will be conditioned on institutions signing loan discharge agreements with students in pre-accredited programs.
